content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A puzzle of quality, no doubt there as been some hard work.

I would like to comment on the 20X20 grids. With my code, after "cleaning up" the completed cages in the initial phase, there are 61 left to process for the test while only 24 remain for the validator. Execution time: 1.02 seconds for the test, 12 ms for the validator.
Perhaps it would be wise to rebalance the difficulties of these grids.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle about a game I did not know.
Statement is clear and the level difficulty is adequate.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Contribution very pleasant to code.
The real challenge is to pass the 20X20 grids.
I advise to solve some of them "online", it is easier to find the method to use!

Interesting puzzle to code. My solution solves all validators but fails the 20X20 test, so I don't know if I can validate the puzzle. Anyway I really enjoyed solving this puzzle and I hope it will be accepted by other Codingamers.
When giving examples, use "e.g." instead of "i.e."

Interesting puzzle, hadn't heard of Suguru before.
If you don't know how to play Suguru, the concept of "cage" and their representation in the inputs is hard to understand, I had to go check the rules elsewhere.
Adding a visual representation of a grid  with the cages would really help imo (for example the grid of the example 4x5).

I'd never heard of Suguru, seems interesting to solve. 

The part about the cage indicators that can be used in different cages is a bit confusing, though. Why not use different letters each time ?
I think becouse it will limit max size of board to max 26x6 cells? See 20x20 test/validator.
Thanks for the suggestion. I have added an example visualization now.
I know the difference between "i.e." and "e.g.", and in my opinion, "that is" sounds better than "for example " in this case since it continues the explanation of the previous sentence.
Well, I solved it in Perl, which isn't exactly the fastest language out there, so it should be possible. You might get some hints if you look at my solution.

Unfortunately, it is not that easy to do. With the method I used to determine suitable numbers for the test grid, it took me many months to do it. The validator uses the original numbers that came with the grid and has approximately 50% more numbers in the grid than the test grid, which is why it is so much easier to solve.
Yes I was amazed when I saw that you had done the code in Perl and I started thinking of more elaborate methods than simple recursion to solve this puzzle. WIP!
Yes it's indeed necessary for big cases, my bad !

It is also part of the problem. I.e., you are not just given the mapping, but you have to identify which cells belong to which cage yourself. Also, coloring the cages in this way is quite common for online Suguru games.

I tried a simple recursive approach but it times out on the 15x10 validator and the 20x20 grids. 
I guess I have to find a way to reduce the action space...
I'll come back to it later, it's fun !
